results_summary: The study found that HFD combined with acidic bile salts (ABS) induced oxidative stress, TNFα, and the Warburg effect in tumors, leading to larger tumors with macrophage infiltration. These effects were abolished by reducing macrophage infiltration or in Nrf2 knockout mice, suggesting a pathway through which MetS may develop GCA.
population_specificity: K19-Wnt1/C2mE (Gan) mice and MKN7 cells co-cultured with THP1-derived macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of pyridoxine (PN) against high-fat diet (HFD)-induced kidney injury and obesity-related complications in rats.
results_summary: HFD caused obesity, inflammation, oxidative stress, and kidney dysfunction in rats. PN intervention mitigated these effects by reducing oxidative stress and restoring antioxidant enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Obese rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of Kumquat fruit (KF) supplementation in counteracting high-fat diet (HFD)-induced neuronal damage and disruption of brain insulin signaling.
results_summary: KF supplementation significantly reduced HFD-induced neuroapoptosis, restored brain insulin signaling, and suppressed neuroinflammation by modulating key apoptotic and inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Murine models of metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between bile acids (BAs) and high-fat diet-induced central precocious puberty (CPP) in female rats, focusing on the roles of gut microbiota and metabolic pathways.
results_summary: The study found that glycodeoxycholic acid (GDCA) levels were reduced in CPP rats, and GDCA treatment delayed puberty onset by modulating gut microbiota, oxidative stress-related metabolites, and Sirt1 expression. Pregnenolone was noted to counteract the beneficial effects of Parasutterella on Sirt1 expression.
population_specificity: Female rats with high-fat diet-induced CPP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of chlorogenic acid (CA) on high-fat diet (HFD)-induced mitochondrial dysfunction and metabolic disorder in skeletal muscle.
results_summary: CA reduced fat accumulation, improved exercise capacity, and enhanced mitochondrial performance in HFD-fed mice. It also improved mitochondrial biogenesis, fatty acid oxidation, and oxidative phosphorylation while reducing lactate production and protein lactylation.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice fed with a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of butyrate in ameliorating obesity-induced spermatogenic dysfunction caused by a high-fat diet (HFD) and explore potential molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that HFD caused decreased sperm count, motility, and increased malformation rates in mice, while butyrate supplementation significantly improved these sperm indicators and restored metabolic pathways like steroid biosynthesis and primary bile acid biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Male mice induced with obesity via HFD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exercise intervention on behavior, inflammatory factors, glial cells, and feeding neurons in animals with high-fat diet-induced hypothalamic inflammation.
results_summary: Exercise intervention generally improved behavior, inflammatory factors, glial cells, and feeding neurons in animals with high-fat diet-induced hypothalamic inflammation, though some studies reported no significant changes in food intake and body weight, and others noted reduced expression of anti-inflammatory factors.
population_specificity: Mice (10 studies) and rabbits (1 study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the structure of fucoidan fractions (LF3-1 and LF4-1) from Saccharina japonica and their mechanism for treating obesity in high-fat-diet-fed mice.
results_summary: The fucoidan mixture (LF3-1 and LF4-1) reduced body weight, improved insulin resistance, ameliorated dyslipidemia, protected intestinal barrier integrity, regulated lipid metabolism, and reduced inflammation in high-fat-diet-fed mice. It also increased beneficial gut bacteria and influenced lipid metabolomics.
population_specificity: High-fat-diet-fed C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether opaganib could suppress weight gain and improve glucose tolerance in mice fed a High-Fat Diet (HFD).
results_summary: Opaganib treatment significantly reduced weight gain and improved glucose tolerance in HFD-fed mice, with effects comparable to semaglutide. It also prevented weight rebound after semaglutide cessation.
population_specificity: Male and female C57BL/6 mice.
effective_dosage: Once daily, 5 days per week (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Lonicerae Japonica Flos (LJF) on liver injury in rats with high-fat diet (HFD)-induced non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: LJF extract significantly improved body weight, daily food intake, liver tissue steatosis, lipid droplet vacuolization, inflammatory cell infiltration, serum biochemical parameters, liver lipid content, inflammatory factors, and oxidative stress markers in HFD-induced NAFLD rats, with the high-dose group showing the most significant improvement.
population_specificity: Rats with HFD-induced NAFLD.
effective_dosage: High-dose group (LJF-H) mentioned, but specific amounts and frequencies not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of hydrogen-rich water (HRW) on spermatogenesis dysfunction in rats with high-fat diet (HFD)-induced obesity.
results_summary: The study found that HFD significantly increased food intake, body weight, and oxidative stress while reducing sperm count and testis weight. HRW treatment improved these parameters by reducing oxidative stress and ameliorating histological changes in the testis and epididymis.
population_specificity: Male Wistar Albino rats
effective_dosage: HRW (1.5 mM) administered orally every day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how a high-fat diet impacts the pharmacokinetics and safety of 8 mg Ondansetron hydrochloride tablets in healthy Chinese individuals.
results_summary: Ondansetron had lower Cmax, AUC0-t, and AUC0-∞ in plasma when taken with a high-fat meal compared to fasting, with 90% confidence intervals outside the acceptable bioequivalence range. Adverse effects were comparable between fasting and postprandial groups.
population_specificity: Healthy Chinese individuals (n=53).
interactions: High-fat diet (978.6 kcal, 54.6% fat) affected Ondansetron pharmacokinetics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of J27, a JNK inhibitor, in mitigating high-fat diet-induced metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) in mice.
results_summary: J27 significantly reduced hepatic steatosis, liver injury, insulin resistance, and inflammatory responses in HFD-fed mice by inhibiting JNK activation, improving insulin signaling in hepatocytes, and disrupting the JNK/NF-κB axis in macrophages.
population_specificity: HFD-induced MASLD mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-fat diet (HFD) consumption during adolescence on mPFC-related behaviors and underlying mechanisms, including potential protective interventions.
results_summary: Mice fed a HFD during adolescence developed depressive- and anxiety-like behaviors, increased risk-avoidance behavior, and morphological aberrations in mPFC neurons and microglia. Minocycline administration attenuated these adverse effects.
population_specificity: Adolescent mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential benefits of xylooligosaccharides combined with L. plantarum ZDY2013 (synbiotic) on T2DM-induced intestinal injury and insulin resistance.
results_summary: The synbiotic improved glucose metabolism, reduced lipid accumulation, alleviated insulin resistance, restored intestinal barrier integrity, suppressed oxidative stress and inflammation, enhanced bacterial colonization, and increased SCFA production in T2DM rats.
population_specificity: T2DM rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a high-fat diet (HFD) influences platelet activation, premetastatic niche formation, and metastasis in breast cancer.
results_summary: A HFD pre-activates platelets and endothelial cells, promoting premetastatic niche formation in the lung, which enhances tumor cell homing and metastasis. Anti-platelet interventions or dietary changes reduced metastasis, and blocking fibronectin decreased tumor-endothelial cell interactions.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) female patients and preclinical models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of purple potato extract on oxidative stress and fat metabolism in the livers of high-fat diet-fed rats.
results_summary: Purple potato extract reduced body weight, improved glucose tolerance, lowered oxidative stress, and positively modulated lipid metabolism genes in high-fat diet-fed rats. It also reduced lipid accumulation and inflammation in hepatic and pancreatic tissues.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how high-fat diets contribute to NAFLD via bacterial LPS and whether butyrate administration could mitigate liver damage by altering the intestinal phageome.
results_summary: Excessive fat intake increased endogenous LPS levels, worsening liver injury, but butyrate administration improved hepatic health by enhancing bacteriophage diversity and reducing mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress. Fecal phage transplantation confirmed that butyrate-modified phages could interact with LPS to lower liver damage.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Yi Mai granule (YMG) on gut microbiota and lipid/carbohydrate metabolism in an NAFLD model using ApoE-/- mice.
results_summary: YMG altered gut microbiota composition and serum metabolites related to lipid and carbohydrate metabolism, suggesting therapeutic effects on NAFLD by modulating these pathways. The study linked YMG's effects to improved blood lipid profiles.
population_specificity: ApoE-/- mice with induced NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the efficacy and mechanisms of raspberry aqueous extract (RE) in alleviating high-fat diet (HFD)-induced metabolic-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD) in mice.
results_summary: RE supplementation significantly reduced HFD-induced liver injury, hepatosteatosis, inflammation, and insulin resistance by regulating fatty acid metabolism and inflammation pathways, particularly the AMPK signaling pathway. The metabolite umbelliferone (UMB) was identified as a key component in RE's therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Mice with HFD-induced MAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hawthorn leaves and vitexin could mitigate obesity-related symptoms and improve gut microbiota diversity in a high-fat diet-induced obese mouse model.
results_summary: Hawthorn leaves and vitexin significantly reduced body weight gain, improved glucose tolerance, regulated blood lipids, and enhanced gut microbiota diversity by altering specific bacterial abundances and metabolite levels.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of linagliptin on inflammasome regulation, inflammation, and adipose tissue dysfunction in obese mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: Linagliptin reduced high-fat diet-induced endotoxemia, circulating inflammatory markers, and visceral adipose tissue inflammation by decreasing NLRC4 inflammasome activity and adipocyte hypertrophy, though subcutaneous adipose tissue showed a milder response. In vitro, linagliptin also reduced pro-inflammatory macrophage polarization.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6N mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of intestinal IL-25 in modulating high-fat diet-induced obesity and its effects on metabolic dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that high-fat diet reduced IL-25 expression in mice, which was inversely associated with metabolic markers like cholesterol and glucose. Overexpression of IL-25 in intestinal epithelial cells reduced fat absorption, cholesterol uptake, and systemic metabolic dysregulation.
population_specificity: Mice (transgenic and wild-type) and human intestinal Caco-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive effects of probiotic Lactiplantibacillus plantarum Lb41 against NAFLD in high-fat diet-fed mice.
results_summary: Lb41 significantly reduced body weight, serum lipids, and hepatic injury markers in HFD-fed mice, while improving lipid metabolism and insulin sensitivity. The probiotic also modulated key metabolic regulators in liver cells, showing potential hepatoprotective effects.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interaction between high-fat diets, obesity, neuroinflammation, and neurodegenerative diseases, specifically focusing on leptin sensitivity and the effects of aerobic exercise.
results_summary: The study found that high-fat diets induced obesity, leptin resistance, and increased neuroinflammation in mice, while 12 weeks of aerobic exercise activated the leptin/LepR/GSK-3β pathway, reducing inflammation and improving memory.
population_specificity: Wild-type and high-fat-diet-fed APP/PS1 transgenic mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-fat diet composition not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic benefits of Renshen-zhuye decoction (RZD) on obesity and insulin resistance induced by a high-fat diet (HFD) in mice and to elucidate its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: RZD treatment dose-dependently improved HFD-induced dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, glucose tolerance, and energy expenditure by modulating gut microbiota composition, enhancing intestinal barrier integrity, and reducing inflammation. Antibiotic intervention negated these benefits, while fecal microbiota transplantation confirmed gut microbiota's role in mediating RZD's effects.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of Salvianolic acid B (SalB) on high-fat diet (HFD)-induced cognitive impairment and its underlying mechanisms in vivo and in vitro.
results_summary: SalB improved motor skills and learning capacity in HFD mice, reduced inflammatory markers, and inhibited the Trem2/Dap12 pathway in both hippocampal tissue and BV2 cells. The study suggests SalB may be a potential therapy for HFD-induced cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: HFD-fed mice and BV2 microglial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the epigenetic mechanisms by which short-term and long-term high-fat diets induce metabolic disorder, focusing on gut microbiota and m6A methylation.
results_summary: Both short-term (4 days) and long-term (10 weeks) high-fat diets increased mRNA m6A levels in adipose tissue, activated transposable elements, and disrupted metabolic health. Gut microbiota alterations and increased homogentisic acid (HGA) were identified as key contributors to these effects.
population_specificity: Mice (epididymal white adipose tissue focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a postnatal high-fat diet (HFD) and maternal obesity alter muscle protein levels related to synthesis and atrophy, and if (-)-epicatechin (Epi) could mitigate these changes.
results_summary: The study found increased levels of atrophy-related proteins (Murf and MAFbx) in gastrocnemius and soleus tissues of rats fed a HFD, particularly in offspring of obese mothers. Epi treatment did not modify these protein levels.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rat offspring, including groups with maternal obesity and postnatal HFD exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a liposomal formulation co-encapsulating α-tocopheryl succinate (TS) and α-tocopherol (T) (TS/T-lipo) on obesity, particularly its ability to inhibit lipid accumulation without cytotoxicity.
results_summary: TS/T-lipo significantly inhibited lipid accumulation in vitro and reduced body weight in a high-fat diet-induced obese mouse model without causing liver toxicity or elevated blood glucose levels. Histological analysis supported the inhibition of lipid accumulation, and increased glycerol serum levels suggested enhanced lipolysis.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether ergosterol (ERG) from Zhashui Auricularia auricula could alleviate obesity and cognitive impairment induced by a high-fat diet (HFD) in mice.
results_summary: ERG reduced obesity-related intestinal microbial genera, lowered lipid levels and liver oxidative stress, and improved memory and learning abilities by restoring hippocampal function and reducing inflammation in HFD-fed mice.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize a reproducible, non-transgenic mouse model of sustained type 2 diabetes (T2D) using a high-fat diet (HFD) combined with streptozotocin (STZ) infusion.
results_summary: The study found that combining HFD with STZ (200 mg/kg) led to increased blood glucose, impaired glucose tolerance, obesity, and hepatic dyslipidaemia, while maintaining reduced but detectable insulin production without overt beta cell loss. The model replicated key pathophysiological changes seen in human T2D.
population_specificity: Adult male C57BL/6 mice
effective_dosage: High-fat diet (unspecified composition) for 17 weeks; STZ (200-350 mg/kg) infused over 14 days

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether irisin intervention could restore the thermogenic function of interscapular brown adipose tissue (iBAT) in mice with high-fat diet-induced obesity and improve systemic metabolism.
results_summary: Prolonged high-fat diet feeding impaired iBAT thermogenic capacity, but 4-week irisin intervention reduced lipid content, increased UCP1 expression, and improved glucose uptake in iBAT, leading to better systemic metabolism. The benefits of irisin were partially suppressed when iBAT was removed, indicating its role depends on iBAT function.
population_specificity: Mice with high-fat diet-induced obesity and iBAT deficiency

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-obesity effects of Rubia akane Nakai fruit extract (RFE) in high-fat diet-induced obese mice and 3T3-L1 adipocytes.
results_summary: RFE inhibited adipogenic differentiation and lipogenesis in 3T3-L1 adipocytes by downregulating key proteins (PPARγ, C/EBPα, SREBP-1) via AMPK activation. In obese mice, RFE improved obesity phenotypes and insulin resistance by suppressing adipogenesis and enhancing insulin sensitivity through GLUT4 upregulation.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice and 3T3-L1 adipocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of GRK2 in pancreatic islet adaptations to an obesogenic diet and its impact on cardiac function.
results_summary: The study found that genetic ablation of GRK2 in adult β-cells delayed metabolic maladaptation to a high-fat diet, improved insulin sensitivity, and protected against obesity-induced cardiac dysfunction. βGRK2KO mice showed better cardiac function and myocardial morphology compared to controls.
population_specificity: Inducible β-cell-specific GRK2 knockout mouse model (βGRK2KO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a high-fat diet (HFD) in inducing PCOS in a rat model and assess the protective effects of Lepidium sativum seed extract (LSSE) on fertility and pregnancy outcomes.
results_summary: The HFD, combined with letrozole, successfully induced PCOS in rats, leading to metabolic and reproductive dysfunction. LSSE treatment improved body weight, glucose levels, hormonal balance, and pregnancy outcomes, with dose-dependent effects.
population_specificity: Female rats with PCOS induced by letrozole and HFD.
effective_dosage: HFD composition: 68% regular rat food pellets, 6% maize oil, 20% milk powder, and 6% ghee.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether maternal zingerone administration could mitigate metabolic dysfunctions in offspring exposed to a maternal high-fat diet.
results_summary: Offspring treated with zingerone showed significant reductions in body weight, glucose, insulin, cholesterol, triglycerides, and leptin levels, along with increased food intake and ghrelin levels, while POMC gene expression was inhibited at higher doses.
population_specificity: Young adult offspring of Wistar rat models exposed to maternal high-fat diet.
study_duration: From day 1 of pregnancy until postnatal day 21, followed by standard diet until postnatal day 42.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of luteoloside on lipid metabolism imbalance in obese mice fed a high-fat diet and elucidate its molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Luteoloside reduced body fat mass, improved lipid and glucose levels, alleviated inflammation, and balanced gut microbiota, with medium-dose treatment showing the most significant effects. It also regulated PPARα protein expression and inhibited lipid synthesis-related proteins.
population_specificity: Obese mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dragon fruit pomace-derived polysaccharides (PDPS) could alleviate metabolic dysfunction induced by a high-fat diet (HFD) in mice.
results_summary: PDPS treatment in HFD-fed mice significantly reduced body weight gain, fat accumulation, cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL-C while increasing HDL-C. It also improved glucose tolerance, reduced liver fat, and exhibited anti-inflammatory effects by lowering pro-inflammatory cytokines. Additionally, PDPS promoted beneficial gut microbiota shifts.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-obesity effects of oat β-glucan against a high-fat diet and elucidate its regulatory mechanism through bile acid metabolism.
results_summary: Higher molecular weight oat β-glucan showed superior anti-obesity effects, likely due to its viscosity and fermentability, by modulating gut microbiota and bile acid metabolism. It increased beneficial bacteria (Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium) and 7-ketodeoxycholic acid, which inactivated ileal FXR-FGF15 signaling, enhancing bile acid synthesis and hepatic lipolysis.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro models based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between Hsd17b13 expression and metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and validate it as a therapeutic target in high-fat diet (HFD)-obese mice.
results_summary: Liver-specific knockdown of Hsd17b13 in HFD-obese mice improved hepatic steatosis, reduced serum ALT and FGF21 levels, and decreased liver fibrosis markers. The intervention also regulated lipid metabolism genes and altered liver lipid composition, increasing phosphatidylcholines and decreasing diacylglycerols.
population_specificity: Obese mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Isoliquiritigenin (ISL) on lipid metabolism and obesity in a high-fat-diet (HFD)-induced obesity model in mice.
results_summary: ISL treatment significantly reduced HFD-induced weight gain, upregulated thermogenic genes, and enhanced BAT activity. Transcriptomic analysis revealed ISL's modulation of metabolic pathways and genes like NNAT and SGK1, suggesting its potential to mitigate obesity.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to an HFD-induced obesity model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether time-restricted feeding (TRF) could mitigate the negative effects of a high-fat diet on the severity of K/BxN serum-transfer arthritis (STA) in mice.
results_summary: The study found that a high-fat diet increased inflammation markers in mice with STA, including edema, pannus formation, and bone erosion. TRF significantly reduced these inflammatory markers, suggesting it may help manage RA symptoms exacerbated by a high-fat diet.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to high-fat diet and K/BxN serum-transfer arthritis (STA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (ad libitum access for HF group, 10-hour feeding window for HF-TRF group).
study_duration: 4 weeks of conditioning before STA induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of FTO inhibition on cognitive function and metabolic parameters in SAMP8 mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: The study found that FTO inhibition improved metabolic disturbances (e.g., glucose tolerance, leptin levels) and cognitive function (e.g., memory, synaptic plasticity) in HFD-fed SAMP8 mice, while also modulating neuroinflammatory and oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Senescence-accelerated mouse prone 8 (SAMP8) mice fed a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pharmacological treatment with FB23, an FTO inhibitor).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fermented wheat germ (FWG) on maternal obesity-related metabolic disorders and placental function in high-fat diet (HFD)-induced obese maternal rats.
results_summary: FWG supplementation alleviated maternal metabolic abnormalities, reduced placental lipid accumulation, oxidative stress, and inflammation, and optimized placental nutrient transport more effectively than non-fermented wheat germ (WG).
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese maternal rats.
study_duration: 10 weeks before conception until gestational day 19.5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether refined highland barley (RHB) could combat obesity-associated insulin resistance compared to whole-grain highland barley (WGHB) in mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: RHB supplementation improved obesity and insulin resistance, enhanced the intestinal barrier, reduced inflammation, promoted beneficial gut bacteria, increased short-chain fatty acid production, and modulated liver gene transcription to downregulate inflammatory genes. Its effects were comparable to WGHB.
population_specificity: Male 6-week-old C57BL/6J mice
effective_dosage: 30% RHB or WGHB supplemented in high-fat diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined effects of puerarin and Hericium erinaceus insoluble dietary fiber on obesity induced by a high-fat diet in mice, focusing on lipid and glucose metabolism, gut microbiota, and serum metabolites.
results_summary: The combination of puerarin and Hericium erinaceus insoluble dietary fiber (LH) significantly reduced body weight, hepatic and adipose lipid accumulation, improved glucose tolerance and dyslipidemia, enhanced gut microbiota diversity, and promoted beneficial metabolic pathways compared to either component alone.
population_specificity: Mice with obesity induced by a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of combining exercise and metformin on diabetic kidney disease (DKD) in a high-fat diet-induced rat model of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The high-fat diet, combined with streptozotocin injections, induced T2DM in rats, leading to reduced autophagic flux, increased oxidative stress, and kidney damage. The combination of exercise and metformin alleviated these effects by improving renal autophagic flux and reducing oxidative stress, fibrosis, and histopathological damage.
population_specificity: Rats with high-fat diet-induced T2DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBO) on angiogenesis and apoptosis in high-fat diet (HFD)-fed mice with limb ischemia, focusing on the role of SIRT1.
results_summary: HBO improved blood flow, vascular density, and reduced apoptosis in HFD-fed mice with limb ischemia. In vitro, HBO restored endothelial cell function under high-glucose and oxygen-glucose deprivation conditions, primarily through SIRT1 activation.
population_specificity: HFD-fed mice with limb ischemia and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) under high-glucose and oxygen-glucose deprivation conditions.
effective_dosage: HBO at 3 ATA, 1 hour/day for 5 days.
study_duration: 8 weeks on HFD, followed by 5 days of HBO treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of Aurantio-obtusin (AO) on obesity-associated NAFLD induced by a high-fat diet (HFD) in ApoE-/- mice.
results_summary: AO treatment significantly improved HFD-induced obesity, hyperlipidemia, and NAFLD symptoms by modulating gut microbiota, enhancing intestinal barrier function, and regulating hepatic lipid metabolism genes.
population_specificity: ApoE-/- mice fed a high-fat diet for 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of time-restricted wheel running on whole-body energy and glucose homeostasis in mice fed a high-fat diet (HFD).
results_summary: Wheel running during the early or late dark phase improved metabolic outcomes, including reduced body weight gain, enhanced glucose tolerance, and decreased ectopic lipid deposition. Late dark phase exercise showed greater benefits, such as improved metabolic flexibility and insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: Male, 8-week-old C57BL/6NTac mice fed a 60% high-fat diet (HFD) or a 10% low-fat diet (LFD).
study_duration: 4 weeks of diet followed by 4 weeks of exercise intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a high-fat diet combined with gliadin on intestinal health and the potential benefits of Bifidobacterium longum strains in mitigating these effects.
results_summary: The study found that a high-fat diet with 6% gliadin negatively impacted duodenal health and gut microbiota, but three B. longum strains improved duodenal morphology, reduced inflammation, and modulated microbiota composition, with B. longum CCFM1216 showing additional benefits for blood lipids and glucose.
population_specificity: Mice on a 10-week high-fat diet with 6% gliadin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Dioscorea opposita polysaccharides (DOP) on insulin resistance, lipid metabolism, oxidative stress, and gut microbiota in high-fat-diet-induced type 2 diabetic rats.
results_summary: DOP supplementation improved body weight, glucose/lipid metabolism, liver oxidative stress, and gut microbiota composition in diabetic rats, suggesting potential benefits for managing high-fat-diet-induced metabolic dysfunction.
population_specificity: High-fat-diet and streptozotocin-induced type 2 diabetic rats.
effective_dosage: Low dose (200 mg/kg BW), high dose (400 mg/kg BW), and D. opposita powder (400 mg/kg BW).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-obesity effects of Hericium erinaceus protein (HEP) and its underlying mechanism in alleviating lipid metabolism disorders induced by a high-fat diet.
results_summary: HEP reduced pancreatic lipase activity, enhanced fat excretion, and improved body weight, dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, hepatic steatosis, and liver oxidative stress in obese mice. It upregulated PPARα and fatty acid oxidation genes while downregulating lipogenesis-related genes.
population_specificity: Obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether combining a low-carbohydrate, high-fat (LCHF) diet with exercise in hypoxia (EH) improved hematological, lipid, inflammatory, and blood pressure outcomes in older patients with type 2 diabetes and hypertension.
results_summary: The study found no significant additional benefits of hypoxia or carbohydrate restriction on blood pressure, lipid profiles, or inflammation markers. Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) increased in the EH group but decreased in the EH+LCHF group, suggesting divergent hematological effects.
population_specificity: Older patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension (42 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lactiplantibacillus plantarum BXM2 supplementation on obesity, intestinal health, and microbiota in mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: L. plantarum BXM2 reduced perirenal adipose index, improved intestinal health markers, regulated inflammation by normalizing TNF-α and IL-6 expression, and reversed gut dysbiosis by altering microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Male SPF C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fermented P. brevitarsis larvae (FPB) could mitigate high-fat diet (HFD)-induced non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) by reducing lipid accumulation and inflammation in the liver.
results_summary: FPB improved HFD-induced dysglycemia, reduced liver and white adipose tissue weight, lowered serum lipid levels, and ameliorated oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, hepatic steatosis, hepatitis, and apoptosis. These effects were mediated through regulation of the AMP-activated protein kinase pathway, nuclear factor-kappa B pathway, and B-cell lymphoma 2 protein family.
population_specificity: The study was conducted on a model of HFD-induced NAFLD, likely in animals (exact species not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between high-fat diet (HFD), gut microbiota alterations, bile acid metabolism, and the development of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: HFD was linked to higher GDM prevalence, gut microbiota dysbiosis, and altered bile acid metabolism, exacerbating glucose intolerance and insulin resistance in mice. Fecal microbiota transplantation and colesevelam intervention confirmed the role of gut microbiota and Fxr pathway in HFD-associated GDM.
population_specificity: Pregnant mice (GDM models) and human GDM patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how host miRNAs influence gut microbiome changes related to metformin treatment in a type 2 diabetes mouse model, particularly under a high-fat diet.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in miRNA expression based on diet and intestinal location, with minor effects from metformin treatment in non-diabetic mice. Key fecal miRNAs targeted specific bacteria, affecting Oscillospiraceae_NOV, Lachnospiraceae_NOV, and Bacteroides.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic male mice and a type 2 diabetes mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of combining fisetin (FSN) and hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) in treating NAFLD induced by a high-fat diet in mice.
results_summary: The FSN + HCQ combination effectively reversed insulin sensitivity, glucose homeostasis, and NAFLD markers by modulating lipid metabolism and inflammation, though HCQ alone exacerbated oxidative stress.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat diet to induce NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of quercetin (QE) on diabetes and its complications, including high-fat diet-induced obesity, by examining in vitro, in vivo, and clinical trial findings.
results_summary: QE demonstrated protective effects against high-fat diet-induced obesity and other diabetes-related complications by modulating inflammatory markers, improving insulin sensitivity, and enhancing glucose uptake. It also attenuated insulin resistance through multiple pathways, including peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor expression and glucose transporter-4 regulation.
population_specificity: Studies included in vitro, in vivo (animal models), and clinical trials, but specific human populations were not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of chicory sesquiterpene lactones (TSLs) on metabolic disorders, intestinal flora, and bile acids in mice fed a high-fat diet (HFD).
results_summary: TSLs, along with total chicory extract (TCE) and pioglitazone (Pio), reduced body weight gain, hepatic lipid accumulation, and improved plasma biochemical parameters in HFD-fed mice. TSLs also altered intestinal flora composition and bile acid levels, suggesting potential benefits for metabolic syndrome (MetS).
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat diet.
study_duration: 8 weeks of HFD feeding followed by 8 weeks of intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the signaling mechanisms between different tissues and organs, particularly the crosstalk involving adipose tissue, to understand obesity-related chronic diseases and explore potential treatment strategies.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that a high-fat diet contributes to obesity and chronic diseases but does not provide specific results on efficacy or safety. It focuses on multi-organ interactions and potential treatment strategies.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of obesity and chronic diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between a high-fat diet, epigenetic reprogramming, and atherosclerosis, focusing on underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The review found that a high-fat diet rich in saturated fatty acids is a risk factor for atherosclerosis, with epigenetics playing a critical role, though the exact mechanisms remain unclear. Existing preclinical and clinical trials suggest that epigenetic drugs may help attenuate atherosclerosis, but larger trials are needed for definitive evidence.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of pregnant mothers and offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of neutrophils and neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in the pathophysiology of obesity and related disorders induced by a high-fat diet (HFD).
results_summary: The study found that HFD-induced obesity leads to neutrophil infiltration and NET formation in adipose tissue, contributing to inflammation. It also highlighted the role of gut microbiota imbalance and increased intestinal permeability in metabolic inflammation, with short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) influencing neutrophil function.
population_specificity: Animal models and humans (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the early pathophysiological effects of high-fat diets (HFD) in rodents to identify the origins of metabolic diseases and improve treatment strategies.
results_summary: The study found that sustained HFD intake in mice led to insulin resistance, fatty liver, and systemic inflammatory responses within a week, resembling key disease features, though single meals did not produce visible effects.
population_specificity: Rodents (mice)
study_duration: Within a week of consecutive HFD meals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the synergistic effects of alcohol and a high-fat diet (HFD) in exacerbating liver injury, using rodent models to simulate human alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD).
results_summary: The study found that a high-fat diet, when combined with alcohol consumption, increases susceptibility to liver injury, contributing to the progression of ALD. The rodent models demonstrated synergistic effects between alcohol and HFD, highlighting potential mechanisms for liver damage.
population_specificity: Rodent models (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify reversible risk factors for breast cancer, including the impact of a high-fat diet, to inform early intervention strategies.
results_summary: The study found that a high-fat diet is linked to a higher risk of breast cancer, alongside other factors like low dietary fiber intake, alcohol consumption, smoking, and obesity. However, the methodological and evidence quality of the reviewed studies was generally low.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of systematic reviews and meta-analyses).
